strategic_profile.executive_summary: Washington University in St. Louis is a premier private research university known for its rigorous academic programs and interdisciplinary approach. Founded in 1853, it consistently ranks among the top national universities and is recognized for its strong commitment to discovery, teaching, and real-world contributions.
strategic_profile.admissions_philosophy: Washington University in St. Louis practices need-blind undergraduate admissions and meets 100 percent of the demonstrated financial need for all admitted students. The university emphasizes fostering intellectual curiosity, critical thinking, creativity, and collaboration, encouraging students to explore diverse perspectives and integrate ideas across fields.

analyst_takeaways.insight: Washington University in St. Louis is highly selective, with overall acceptance rates around 12-13%. Early Decision (ED) offers a significantly higher acceptance rate (25-27%) compared to Regular Decision (RD) which can be as low as 8-9%.
analyst_takeaways.implication: Applicants for whom WashU is a top choice should strongly consider applying Early Decision (ED1 or ED2) to substantially increase their chances of admission, demonstrating a binding commitment.

analyst_takeaways.insight: WashU emphasizes academic flexibility and interdisciplinary study, offering over 100 fields of study and programs like 'Beyond Boundaries' that encourage students to explore connections across different undergraduate divisions and graduate schools.
analyst_takeaways.implication: Prospective students should highlight their intellectual curiosity, desire for interdisciplinary learning, and specific interests that align with WashU's flexible curriculum and special programs in their essays and interviews.

analyst_takeaways.insight:
The university fosters a collaborative and supportive environment rather than an overly competitive one,
with a strong sense of community among students.
analyst_takeaways.implication: Applicants should emphasize experiences showcasing teamwork, collaboration, and a desire to contribute positively to a supportive community in their application materials and supplemental essays.

campus_dynamics.social_environment: Washington University in St. Louis offers a welcoming and collaborative academic environment, characterized by a friendly and supportive community that balances ambition with teamwork rather than cutthroat competition. Students often highlight a vibrant, intellectually driven atmosphere, though some reviews suggest a less energetic social scene compared to other universities. The university also ranks highly for student quality of life and friendliness.
campus_dynamics.transportation_impact: The campus is easily walkable and highly connected to the regional transit system, Metro Transit, with two MetroLink stops on the Danforth Campus and others at different campuses. All full-time students, faculty, and staff receive a free U-Pass for unlimited access to MetroLink and MetroBus services. Additionally, an extensive shuttle network connects various campuses and surrounding neighborhoods, including a free Campus Circulator. Biking is also a viable and encouraged option for getting around.
campus_dynamics.research_impact: Washington University in St. Louis provides strong undergraduate research opportunities across various disciplines, with students, including freshmen, able to engage in faculty-mentored and project-based inquiry. The university offers numerous summer research programs, such as ASPIRE, ASSURE, and initiatives through the Institute for Informatics and Public Health. Significant research funding, particularly within the Medical School, enables undergraduates to participate in paid research projects, and opportunities are also available in the McKelvey School of Engineering.

current_status.test_policy_details: Washington University in St. Louis has adopted a test-optional policy for applicants for admission in the fall semester of 2026. Applicants have the option of whether to submit standardized test scores. Students who are unable to or who elect not to submit their test scores will have the requirement automatically waived and will not be penalized. For those who do submit test scores, either SAT or ACT scores are acceptable, and neither the writing section nor SAT Subject Tests are required. Test results from any of the student's high school years are acceptable. WashU accepts self-reported scores on the Common and Coalition applications. If a student enrolls at WashU and submitted unofficial scores, official score reports from testing agencies will then be required. For the ACT, WashU considers the highest section scores across all the test dates submitted. If a student takes both the ACT and SAT, WashU will consider whichever set of scores is most advantageous. WashU will 'Super Score' ACT or SAT scores and consider the highest section scores across all test dates submitted (individual section retakes are accepted on the ACT). The last test date accepted will be the December testing (October if applying Early Decision I).

longitudinal_trends.notes: Second-largest cohort in the school's history. Noted increase in rural and international students, and a decrease in first-generation and low-income students. Need-blind admissions policy continued. Test-optional policy in effect.
Increased percentage of students from rural communities, low-income, or first-generation college students. This was the first class since the U.S. Supreme Court banned race-conscious admissions.
Need-blind undergraduate admissions policy was in effect. Early decision acceptance rate was 26% and regular decision acceptance rate was 9%.

Achieved a record low acceptance rate at the time. This was the first class admitted after the full implementation of need-blind admissions and a new committee-based evaluation process. Noted increase in Pell Grant-eligible, first-generation, and students of color compared to previous years.
The university officially adopted a need-blind undergraduate-admissions policy in 2021. Described as the largest and most diverse class at the time.

gpa.notes: 86% of students reporting rank were in the top 10% of their high school class

testing.policy_note: Washington University in St. Louis is test-optional. They superscore both SAT and ACT, considering the highest section scores across all test dates. Applicants can self-report scores, with official scores required upon enrollment.

demographics.notes: First-generation percentage is for the Class of 2028. Legacy percentage (12-13%) is an estimate from a Quora discussion, not an official university statistic. Legacy defined as alumni children.

colleges.name: College of Arts & Sciences
colleges.housing_profile: High-quality, modern, and traditional residential halls primarily located on the South 40 for first and second-year students. Dorms feature soft beds, air conditioning, and often suite-style bathrooms, with some traditional halls having communal facilities. Each residential community includes social lounges, study rooms, personal computing labs, and recreation rooms, fostering a strong sense of community.
colleges.student_archetype: Intellectually curious and adaptable individuals who are interested in interdisciplinary studies and pushing boundaries within and among various academic disciplines. These students are committed to social impact, global engagement, and developing multiple literacies (digital, media, economic) to understand and serve the world.
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Applicants who thrive in a diverse and inclusive learning environment, are eager to explore a wide range of subjects, and aspire to engage deeply with complex societal and global issues through critical inquiry and innovative thought.

application_deadlines.notes: This refers to Early Decision I.

supplemental_requirements.details: One required short answer essay (250 words or less) asking about your academic interests and why you want to study them at WashU. An optional writing supplement (250 words or less) allows you to respond to one of two prompts: either discuss a community you are a part of and your impact within it, or describe how your life experiences have shaped your story. An optional video supplement is also available.

holistic_factors.specific_differentiators: Employs a holistic and individualized review process to build a welcoming, nurturing, and intellectually rigorous community, actively seeking students who demonstrate intellectual curiosity and will contribute distinctly to the university. Offers optional interviews as an opportunity for the admissions committee to learn more about the applicant.

essay_prompts.prompt: Please tell us what you are interested in studying at college and why. Undecided about your academic interest(s)? Don't worrytell us what excites you about the academic division you selected. Remember that all of our first-year students enter officially undeclared and work closely with their team of academic advisors to discover their academic passions. You can explore all of our majors and programs on our website.
brainstorming_questions: What specific courses, professors, or research opportunities at WashU are most compelling to your academic interests?
Describe a moment, book, or experience that first ignited your curiosity in this particular field or academic division.
How have you explored this interest outside of your high school curriculum (e.g., projects, clubs, online courses, personal reading)?
If undecided, what themes, big questions, or types of problems within your chosen academic division genuinely excite you?
Beyond the subject matter itself, what kind of impact or understanding do you hope to gain by studying this at WashU?

essay_prompts.prompt:
WashU is a place that values a wide range of perspectives. We believe those perspectives come from a variety of experiences and identities. In 250 words or less, respond to one of the following prompts to help us understand Who are you?: 

A. WashU supports engagement in the St. Louis community by considering the university as In St. Louis, For St. Louis. What is a community you are a part of and your place or impact within it?

B. WashU strives to know every undergraduate student By Name & Story. How have your life experiences shaped your story?
brainstorming_questions: For Prompt A: What is a community (broadly defined: family, club, neighborhood, online group, etc.) where you feel you genuinely belong and contribute?
For Prompt A: Can you recall a specific instance where your actions or presence significantly impacted this community, or how the community profoundly impacted you?
For Prompt B: Identify a pivotal life experience or a series of experiences that fundamentally altered your perspective or shaped a core belief you hold today.
For Prompt B: How has this experience informed the person you are becoming or the values you prioritize?
Across both prompts: What unique facet of your identity, experience, or perspective would WashU's admissions committee not discover elsewhere in your application?

major_selection_tactics: Apply to the division that genuinely interests you, rather than trying to game the system with a 'less competitive' major. Washington University in St. Louis encourages applicants to select one of the academic divisions (Architecture, Art, Arts & Sciences, Business, or Engineering) based on their primary interests. While an intended major is indicated during the application, formal declaration often doesn't occur until the second year. WashU emphasizes a holistic review process and states that all undergraduate schools generally have similar admissions criteria.

Consider that popular majors like Computer Science, Finance, and Engineering are likely highly competitive. The most popular majors at WashU include Computer Science, Finance, Research and Experimental Psychology, Economics, and Mechanical Engineering. While there isn't explicit information stating these are harder to get into directly, their popularity suggests a competitive applicant pool.

Be aware that transferring between undergraduate schools (divisions) at WashU is generally considered feasible, but requires careful planning. While some sources suggest internal transfer between schools is 'very easy' or 'quite easy,' others advise caution, noting it typically requires departmental approval and demonstrating the ability to complete the new school's requirements within the four-year timeframe.

Leverage Early Decision if WashU is your top choice, as it significantly increases your chances of admission. The acceptance rate for Early Decision (ED1 and ED2 combined) is substantially higher (25-33%) compared to the Regular Decision acceptance rate (8-10%). Over half of the incoming class is often filled through Early Decision rounds. While not directly about major, applying ED can be a strategic move for overall admission, which then allows you to pursue your chosen major within the university.
application_strategy.alternate_major_strategy: If applying to competitive major, list backup in different college. Example: if applying to CS in Engineering, list Cognitive Science as alternate.
application_strategy.internal_transfer_difficulty: Competitive internal transfer process for impacted majors

scholarships.name: John B. Ervin Scholars Program
scholarships.amount: Full or partial tuition scholarships with a $2,500 annual stipend
scholarships.deadline: January 2, 2026 (application for admission and scholarship essay/short answer)
scholarships.benefits: Special orientation, meetings with university and community leaders, academic support and advising, participation in campus organizations and community service projects. Renewable annually.
scholarships.application_method: Separate Application (requires admission application, scholarship essay/short answer, and optional third letter of recommendation). Finalists interviewed.

scholarships.name: Annika Rodriguez Scholars Program
scholarships.amount: Full or partial tuition scholarships with a $2,500 annual stipend
scholarships.deadline: January 2, 2026 (application for admission and scholarship essay/short answer)
scholarships.benefits: Orientation, meetings with university and community leaders, academic support and advising, Rodriguez First-Year Seminar, and events with other scholars. Renewable annually.
scholarships.application_method: Separate Application (requires admission application, scholarship essay/short answer, and optional third letter of recommendation). Finalists interviewed.

scholarships.name: Danforth Scholars Program
scholarships.deadline: January 2 (scholarship application due, aligned with regular decision admission deadline)
scholarships.benefits: Enriched academic experiences, significant financial support, close-knit community of peers and mentors, opportunities for intellectual exploration, personal growth, and professional development. Renewable annually.
scholarships.application_method: Separate Application (part of Signature Scholar Programs application, requires short answer and essay questions)

scholarships.name: Howard Nemerov Writing Scholars Program
scholarships.deadline: January 2, 2026 (application for admission and writing portfolio)
scholarships.benefits: Participation in writing seminars, submission of work to campus publications, involvement in writing-related social activities, commitment to earning a minor in English writing. Renewable annually.
scholarships.application_method: Separate Application (requires application to the College of Arts & Sciences and submission of a writing portfolio). Finalists notified by end of February.

scholarships.name: Florence Moog Scholarship
scholarships.amount: Half-tuition for junior and senior years
scholarships.deadline: Late March (eligible sophomores receive email in late February with application details)
scholarships.benefits: Recognizes outstanding sophomore in Arts & Sciences preparing for a science career with excellence in STEM and another distinct area.
scholarships.application_method: Separate Application (eligible sophomores in Arts & Sciences with 3.5+ GPA and coursework in natural sciences/math/engineering are invited to apply. Finalists interviewed during Reading Period.)

scholarships.name: Ampersand Scholarships
scholarships.amount: Up to 16 full-tuition scholarships with $1,000 stipends
scholarships.benefits: Priority review for Ampersand Programs, renewable annually.
scholarships.application_method: Automatic Consideration (selected based on application for admission to College of Arts & Sciences, demonstrating strong academic interest in at least two subjects across Humanities, Natural Sciences, and Social Sciences)

scholarships.name: Need-Based Grant
scholarships.amount: Varies (WashU meets 100% of demonstrated financial need without loans)
scholarships.deadline: February 2 (Regular Decision), January 13 (Early Decision II), November 18 (Early Decision I). For continuing students, March 31, 2026.
scholarships.benefits: Covers demonstrated financial need, may include grants and campus store credit for essentials.
scholarships.application_method: CSS Profile and FAFSA (for U.S. citizens/permanent residents). International applicants submit CSS Profile by admission decision plan deadlines.

ap_policy.general_rule: Score of 4+ grants credit for most exams
exceptions: In French and German, a score of 3 confirmed by a course taken in residence earns additional credit
For Chemistry, a score of 4 grants 3 units of CHEM 1030, and a score of 5 grants 3 units of CHEM 1030 and 3 units of CHEM 1040

For History (American, European, World Modern), a score of 5 can fulfill introductory course requirements for the major/minor and grants 3 units of credit, while a score of 4 grants 3 units of elective credit
A score of 5 on AP Psychology waives the PSYCH 1000 Introduction to Psychology requirement, but no college credit is awarded
For Biology, scores of 4 or 5 grant 6 units of elective credit (BIOL 1996)
ap_policy.usage: A maximum of 15 units of pre-matriculation credit may be counted toward any undergraduate degree, which will count toward graduation but not meet general education requirements. These credits can satisfy some major prerequisites and allow for placement into advanced courses.

ib_policy.general_rule: HL exams with 5+ grant credit; SL not accepted. A maximum of 15 units of pre-matriculation credit (including IB) may be applied, counting toward graduation but not general education requirements.

tools: School/program-specific offices (e.g., Olin Global Programs, Sam Fox School Registrar's Office, WashU Continuing & Professional Studies Student Success Navigators)
transfer_policy.restrictions: For general undergraduate transfer, a maximum of 15 units of pre-matriculation or non-Washington University transfer credit (including AP, IB, and British A-Level exams) may be counted toward an undergraduate degree. Courses must have a grade of C or better to be considered for transfer. Grades for transfer courses do not factor into the WashU GPA. Washington University does not transfer credits for courses taken online. For WashU Continuing & Professional Studies (CAPS) Bachelor of Science degrees, a maximum of 66 units from a community college may be transferred, or a maximum of 60 credits from approved Associate in Applied Science programs.

what_it_takes: Strong academic record with challenging coursework and high standardized test scores
Demonstrated genuine passion and long-term dedication in extracurricular activities
Authentic and compelling essays that highlight personality, story, and fit
Active and meaningful involvement in extracurriculars, often demonstrating leadership or deep interest
common_activities: Leadership in school clubs/student organizations: WashU emphasizes leadership roles within the "4 tiers of extracurriculars," and involvement in the more than 400 recognized student groups, including academic, cultural, and pre-professional organizations, is common.

Community service/volunteering: Volunteer work and participation in community service are explicitly considered "important" factors in admissions. Student-run organizations like Pediatric Lifesavers, which works with St. Louis Children's Hospital, exemplify this involvement.

Research experience: Opportunities to learn, conduct research, and experience life on a college campus are offered through summer and pre-college programs. Student interest groups, particularly within the medical school, also facilitate research and shadowing opportunities.

Varsity/club/intramural athletics: WashU students have numerous opportunities to stay active through varsity, club, or intramural athletics. While recruited athletes are considered, the school maintains the same academic requirements.

Music/arts involvement: For students applying to the College of Art, a portfolio demonstrating artistic skill and talent is important. There are also student organizations such as the Business of the Arts Club.

Academic and Pre-professional groups: Many student groups are categorized as academic or pre-professional, such as the WashU Marketing Association and the WashU Real Estate Investment Club, providing resources, networking, and hands-on experience.
essay_tips: Applicants should highlight their intellectual curiosity, desire for interdisciplinary learning, and specific interests that align with WashU's flexible curriculum and special programs in their essays and interviews.
Ensure your essays specifically address WashU's prompts and demonstrate genuine interest in the institution, avoiding generic responses.
Elaborate on the depth and impact of your extracurricular activities, detailing what you gained from them.
Seek strong and personal letters of recommendation from teachers or counselors who know you well.
Demonstrate genuine interest and fit with WashU, potentially through optional interviews or by applying Early Decision if it's your top choice.
red_flags: Generic essays that do not specifically address WashU's prompts or demonstrate genuine interest in the institution
Submitting a list of extracurricular activities without elaborating on their depth, impact, or what you gained from them
Weak or impersonal letters of recommendation from teachers or counselors who do not know you well or cannot speak to your unique qualities
Failing to demonstrate genuine interest and fit with WashU, either through your application materials, optional interviews, or by not applying Early Decision if it is truly your first choice

insights.insight: Washington University in St. Louis is highly selective, with overall acceptance rates around 12-13%. Early Decision (ED) offers a significantly higher acceptance rate (25-27%) compared to Regular Decision (RD) which can be as low as 8-9%.

WashU emphasizes academic flexibility and interdisciplinary study, offering over 100 fields of study and programs like 'Beyond Boundaries' that encourage students to explore connections across different undergraduate divisions and graduate schools.
The university fosters a collaborative and supportive environment rather than an overly competitive one, with a strong sense of community among students.

housing_profile_by_college.housing_profile: High-quality, modern, and traditional residential halls primarily located on the South 40 for first and second-year students. Dorms feature soft beds, air conditioning, and often suite-style bathrooms, with some traditional halls having communal facilities. Each residential community includes social lounges, study rooms, personal computing labs, and recreation rooms, fostering a strong sense of community.
housing_profile_by_college.student_archetype: Intellectually curious and adaptable individuals who are interested in interdisciplinary studies and pushing boundaries within and among various academic disciplines. These students are committed to social impact, global engagement, and developing multiple literacies (digital, media, economic) to understand and serve the world.
housing_profile_by_college.strategic_fit_advice: Applicants who thrive in a diverse and inclusive learning environment, are eager to explore a wide range of subjects, and aspire to engage deeply with complex societal and global issues through critical inquiry and innovative thought.

housing_profile_by_college.college_name: Sam Fox School of Design & Visual Arts
housing_profile_by_college.housing_profile: High-quality, modern, and traditional residential halls primarily located on the South 40 for first and second-year students. Dorms feature soft beds, air conditioning, and often suite-style bathrooms, with some traditional halls having communal facilities. Each residential community includes social lounges, study rooms, personal computing labs, and recreation rooms, fostering a strong sense of community.
housing_profile_by_college.student_archetype: Creative, passionate, and socially conscious individuals who believe in the power of design, architecture, and art to address difficult questions and create impactful solutions for local and global communities. Students are often interested in sustainability, environmental justice, and social justice through design.
housing_profile_by_college.strategic_fit_advice: Ideal for aspiring architects, artists, and designers who are innovative, collaborative, and dedicated to using their creative skills to tackle real-world challenges, particularly in areas of sustainability and community engagement.

housing_profile_by_college.housing_profile: High-quality, modern, and traditional residential halls primarily located on the South 40 for first and second-year students. Dorms feature soft beds, air conditioning, and often suite-style bathrooms, with some traditional halls having communal facilities. Each residential community includes social lounges, study rooms, personal computing labs, and recreation rooms, fostering a strong sense of community.
housing_profile_by_college.student_archetype: Ambitious, analytical, and purpose-driven students aspiring to leadership roles. They are interested in solving real-world business problems, sharpening analytical skills, and making a positive impact on society through business. A strong interest in areas like the business of health and entrepreneurship is common.
housing_profile_by_college.strategic_fit_advice: This school is suitable for students who seek a world-class business education with a focus on experiential learning, global perspectives, and developing into principled leaders who can leverage business as a force for good.

housing_profile_by_college.housing_profile: High-quality, modern, and traditional residential halls primarily located on the South 40 for first and second-year students. Dorms feature soft beds, air conditioning, and often suite-style bathrooms, with some traditional halls having communal facilities. Each residential community includes social lounges, study rooms, personal computing labs, and recreation rooms, fostering a strong sense of community.
housing_profile_by_college.student_archetype: Problem-solvers with a strong STEM background and a passion for independent inquiry, scientific excellence, technological innovation, and equitable societal impact. These students are eager to explore, create, and design solutions to complex challenges in an evolving world.
housing_profile_by_college.strategic_fit_advice: Applicants should have a strong aptitude for science and mathematics, a desire for hands-on, experiential learning, and a commitment to applying engineering principles to generate new knowledge and contribute to positive systematic change globally.
